metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: We will use the "books.xml" document in the examples below (same XML file as in the previous chapters).
content.html: We will use the "books.xml" document in the examples below (same XML file as in the previous chapters).

links.text: View the "books.xml" file in your browser

content.text: View the "books.xml" file in your browser .
content.html: View the "books.xml" file in your browser.

content.text: Adding Elements and Attributes to the Result
As we have seen in a previous chapter, we may include elements and attributes from the input document ("books.xml) in the result:
content.html: As we have seen in a previous chapter, we may include elements and attributes from the input document ("books.xml) in the result:

content.code:
for $x in doc("books.xml")/bookstore/book/title

order by $x

return $x
content.code_html:
for $x in doc("books.xml")/bookstore/book/title
order by $x
return $x

content.text: The XQuery expression above will include both the title element and the lang attribute in the result, like this:
content.html: The XQuery expression above will include both the title element and the lang attribute in the result, like this:

content.code:
<title lang="en">Everyday Italian</title>

<title lang="en">Harry Potter</title>

<title lang="en">Learning XML</title>

<title lang="en">XQuery Kick Start</title>
content.code_html:
<title lang="en">Everyday Italian</title>
<title lang="en">Harry Potter</title>
<title lang="en">Learning XML</title>
<title lang="en">XQuery Kick Start</title>

content.text: The XQuery expression above returns the title elements the exact same way as they are described in the input document.
content.html: The XQuery expression above returns the title elements the exact same way as they are described in the input document.

content.text: We now want to add our own elements and attributes to the result!
content.html: We now want to add our own elements and attributes to the result!

content.text: Now, we want to add some HTML elements to the result. We will put the result in an HTML list - together with some text:
content.html: Now, we want to add some HTML elements to the result. We will put the result in an HTML list - together with some text:

content.code:
Bookstore

    { for $x in doc("books.xml")/bookstore/book order by $x/title return
  • {data($x/title)}. Category: {data($x/@category)}
    • }
content.code_html:
<html>
<body>

<h1>Bookstore</h1>

<ul>
{
for $x in doc("books.xml")/bookstore/book
order by $x/title
return <li>{data($x/title)}. Category: {data($x/@category)}</li>
}
</ul>

</body>
</html>

content.text: The XQuery expression above will generate the following result:
content.html: The XQuery expression above will generate the following result:

content.code:
Bookstore

  • Everyday Italian. Category: COOKING
  • Harry Potter. Category: CHILDREN
  • Learning XML. Category: WEB
  • XQuery Kick Start. Category: WEB
content.code_html:
<html>
<body>

<h1>Bookstore</h1>

<ul>
<li>Everyday Italian. Category: COOKING</li>
<li>Harry Potter. Category: CHILDREN</li>
<li>Learning XML. Category: WEB</li>
<li>XQuery Kick Start. Category: WEB</li>
</ul>

</body>
</html>

content.text: Next, we want to use the category attribute as a class attribute in the HTML list:
content.html: Next, we want to use the category attribute as a class attribute in the HTML list:

content.code:
Bookstore

    { for $x in doc("books.xml")/bookstore/book order by $x/title return
  • {data($x/title)}
    • }
content.code_html:
<html>
<body>

<h1>Bookstore</h1>

<ul>
{
for $x in doc("books.xml")/bookstore/book
order by $x/title
return <li class="{data($x/@category)}">{data($x/title)}</li>
}
</ul>

</body>
</html>

content.text: The XQuery expression above will generate the following result:
content.html: The XQuery expression above will generate the following result:

content.code:
Bookstore

  • Everyday Italian
  • Harry Potter
  • Learning XML
  • XQuery Kick Start
content.code_html:
<html>
<body>
<h1>Bookstore</h1>

<ul>
<li class="COOKING">Everyday Italian</li>
<li class="CHILDREN">Harry Potter</li>
<li class="WEB">Learning XML</li>
<li class="WEB">XQuery Kick Start</li>
</ul>

</body>
</html>
